newsitem.title: GREECE: PRESS DIGEST - GREEK GENERAL NEWS- APRIL 11.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - GREEK GENERAL NEWS- APRIL 11.

text.p: Leading stories in the Greek general press:

--Press reports have Prime Minister Costas Simitis and his Turkish counterpart Necmettin Erbakan meeting on the sidelines of the June NATO summit. Athens, it is reported, wants to sign a non-agression pact with Turkey.

--Greece's Government Council on Foreign Affairs and Defence will rubberstamp the Greek mission to the Albanian multinational protection force next week, after the first troops have left for the neighbouring country.

--The government will re-examine the possibility of additional measures to boost state inflows at the beginning of the summer and, for the time being, is banking on an improvement with the first income tax inflows in May and yesterday's start to the operation of the new economic crimes squad.

--Following pressure from Europe and the US on both Athens and Ankara, both governments are moving towards rapprochement. Dialogue between has effectively begun and expert committees are beginning to be established.
--Prime Minister Costas Simitis yesterday outlined his proposals for radical changes to labour relations, targeting "workers' privileges" while criticising neo-conservative tendencies.

--The municipality of Thessaloniki - Europe's Cultural Capital this year - is drowning in debt and there are concerns that the city may have to cancel a number of planned cultural events due to lack of venues and lack of funds and time to fix those that exist.

--A 35-year-old taxi driver confessed yesterday to a decade-long spree in which he killed five people and attempted to kill another six. Short and slight Dimitris Vakrinos said he killed because he felt powerful with a gun in his hand.
--The 'Rambos' of the finance ministry, the new economic crimes squad, began their surprise on-the-spot checks of firms in the Attica region yesterday.
--New internal problems in ruling party PASOK as 25 MPs express their disagreement with plans to decentralise and merge local government organisations.
--Greeks have been chilled by the revelations of the murders of five innocent people by taxi driver Vakrinos.
